In this study, the experiments combined with activity tests and characterizations were conducted to investigate the influence of hydrothermal aging (HTA) on the reactivity of NH3-SCR over a Cu-CHA catalyst. The results showed that the NOx conversion efficiency can reach more than 80% below 225 ℃ in the reaction between NH3 and NO+O2 after hydrothermal aging, but it increases the N2O production. The wave spectrum of in-situ DRIFTs confirmed the notable differences in the NH3-SCR mechanism between Cu species of ZCu(OH) and Z2Cu at the same reaction conditions. The NH3-SCR reaction occurring on ZCu(OH) followed the ‘Langmuir-Hinshelwood’ (L-H) mechanism, where NH3 combined with products that oxidize NO to NO2 via dimerization and disproportionation reactions to produce the key intermediates as NH4NO2 and HONO. However, the entire NH3-SCR on Z2Cu followed the ‘Eley-Rideal’ (E-R) mechanism, in which adsorbed NH3 effectively reacted with gas-phase NO to form H2NNO and then produced N2. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords NH3-SCR Cu-CHA Hydrothermal aging Reaction pathway Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) as a reducing agent is the main measure to treat NOx emissions from heavy-duty diesel exhaust, which can convert NOx emissions to N2. Due to the exhaust temperature of diesel engine tended to lower, N2O as a greenhouse needs to be tightly regulated. Cu-based small pore molecular sieve catalyst (Cu-CHA) is now the mainstream commercial NH3-SCR catalyst because of its superior low-temperature activity, low N2O selectivity, recoverability to HC poisoning, and good hydrothermal stability [1–5]. It has been widely accepted that NH3-SCR consists of three main catalytic reduction reactions in order of reaction rate, namely fast SCR (1), standard SCR (2), and slow SCR (3). The NOx emission in diesel exhaust comprises nearly 90% NO, in which standard SCR is the most dominant reaction in the NH3-SCR after-treatment system. (1.1) 2 N H 3 + N O + N O 2 → N 2 + H 2 O (1.2) 4 N H 3 + 4 N O + O 2 → N 2 + H 2 O (1.3) 4 N H 3 + 3 N O 2 → 3.5 N 2 + 6 H 2 O Therefore, an advanced understanding of the standard SCR mechanism has significant implications to improve denitrification efficiency and reduce by-product production over Cu-based catalysts. Numerous research over the years has examined the efficiency of pure zeolites containing H+ in the fast NH3-SCR reaction, whereas it has been demonstrated that active metals with redox ability are essential for enabling the standard NH3-SCR reaction. However, new studies have brought out the significance of NH3-solvated isolated Cu species, which are believed to have a significant part in the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism. The creation of more effective and efficient catalysts for NH3-SCR applications might be facilitated by a better understanding of the complex interactions between these various factors. Usberti et al. [6] suggested the possible role of Cu2+ dimeric complexes in the reduction half-cycle (RHC) of standard SCR by investigating the reactivity of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites over a model Cu-CHA catalyst by transient kinetic tests. Many researchers focused on studying the redox cycle of Cu2+↔Cu+ over Cu active sites. Paolucci et al. [7] found that the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ required the presence of both NO and NH3, while the oxidation of Cu+ to Cu2+ was facilitated by a NO2 intermediate formed by the reaction between NO and O2. These findings were supported by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Moreover, the detailed intermediates and NH3-SCR pathways based on ‘L-H’ and ‘E-R’ mechanisms were also extensively investigated by in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTs) and DFT calculations. Chen et al. [8] proposed complete NH3-SCR pathways over Cu-based catalysts by DFT calculations, which revealed that the Cu site carried the role of oxygen activation and the formation of key intermediates HONO and H2NNO while Brønsted acid sites facilitated the decomposition of HONO and H2NNO to N2 and H2O. Su et al. [9] found that the SCR reaction mainly occurred between adsorbed NH3 on Lewis acid sits and NOx adsorbed species using in situ DRIFTs and temperature-programmed surface reaction. The NO2 - formed directly in this reaction could be easily consumed by NH3 instead of undergoing further oxidation to nitrates. Hu et al. [10] suggested possible reaction step on ZCu(OH), which was NO activation to HONO and reacted with NH3 to form NH4NO2 that could directly decompose to N2. At the same time, NO could not activated on Z2Cu, which was rationalized by DFT calculation. Nevertheless, the entire RHC on ZCu(OH) and Z2Cu requires more detailed investigations, which is the possible reason why the L-H mechanism and the E-R mechanism are controversial. Our previous study [11] found that the redox cycle of NH3-SCR depended on active Cu2+ species located on Lewis acid sites. The migration of ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu during hydrothermal aging is thought to disrupt the redox cycle and affect the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism. Therefore, the purpose of this article is to further study the effect of hydrothermal aging on the reaction activity of NH3-SCR on Cu-CHA catalyst, reveal the intermediate products in the reaction process after hydrothermal aging by method of characterization, and clarify the reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR under hydrothermal aging conditions. It provides data support and theoretical basis for the complete NH3-SCR reaction mechanism and the synthesis of low N2O selective Cu-based catalyst under different conditions. The activity evaluation tests were conducted to investigate the changes in SCR activity and NO/NO2/N2O production upon hydrothermal aging. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), and DRIFTs characterizations were used to disclose the adsorption capacity of NH3 and NO+O2. Finally, the intermediates of the NH3-SCR reaction were detected by in situ DRIFTs to reveal the reaction pathways of NH3-SCR over the fresh and aging catalysts at low temperatures. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The H-CHA zeolite with Si/Al ratio of 22 purchased from Clariant International Company and mixed with 85% SSZ-13 (Analytical Reagent) and 15% SAPO-34 (Analytical Reagent). Cu (CH3COO)2·H2O (Analytical Reagent) was used as a precursor and the Cu-CHA catalysts were synthesized by the ion-exchanged (I.E.) [12–17] method. The target copper content of the Cu-CHA catalyst prepared by us is 2.6%, but in the ion exchange process, it is usually carried out several times of extraction and filtration washing. All the prepared powder was dried at 120 ℃ for 8 h and sintered at 500 ℃ for 2 h, and the Cu loading was detected as 2.02 wt% by elemental analysis using the inductively coupled plasma (ICP). Part of the powder was prepared as a slurry and then coated on cordierite monoliths (400 cpsi). 2.2 Aging and activity measurements The hydrothermal aging and NH3-SCR activity measurements were tested in the simulated gas experimental platform with a sample (a diameter of 24 mm and a length of 50 mm) fixed between the second and third heating zones, as displayed in Fig. 1. The inlet temperature of the catalyst samples, was measured by the thermocouples placed in the front of Cu-CHA catalysts. The outlet gas concentration was detected by MKS Multi-Gas 6030, which allows continuous and fast online measurements. The catalysts were subjected to hydrothermal aging at a temperature of 750 ℃ for durations of 24 and 48 h in a compressed air gas atmosphere containing 10% H2O. The flow rate was maintained at 1000 ml/min throughout the aging process. The experiments for NH3-SCR and NH3-TPD were both conducted on the simulated gas experiment platform. The test conditions for the standard NH3-SCR were as follows: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 8% O2, 5% CO2 and N2 as balance gas. The test conditions for NO oxidation were as follows: 500 ppm NO, 8% O2, 5% CO2 and N2 as balance gas. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of the above tests were both 40,000 h−1, which was equivalent to 15,000 ml/min by flow rate conversion. The NOx conversion of activity evaluation was calculated by the formula (2.1). For the NH3-TPD experiment, the pretreatment of samples was conducted under 500 ℃ for 1 h in compressed air [6,18]. Then, the NH3 adsorption was saturated at 150 ℃ by passing 1000 ppm NH3 for 20 min. After 20 min, NH3 was disconnected, and the catalyst samples were allowed to purge under the N2 atmosphere for 10 min. Eventually, keeping the equilibrium gas constant increased the temperature up to 700 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min. (2.1) N O x c o n v e r s i o n = N O x ( i n ) − N O x ( o u t ) N O x ( i n ) × 100 % 2.3 Catalysts characterization DRIFTs experiments were performed on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer, in which pretreatments were conducted at 300 °C for 30 min under an N2 atmosphere at 250 ml/min. The background spectra were collected at specific test temperatures. The NH3/NO+O2 adsorption experiments were exposed to the corresponding temperature with 500 ppm NH3/500 ppm NO+ 8% O2. The NH3-SCR reactions of pre-adsorbed NH3 or NO+O2 were exposed to a continuous pass of 500 ppm NH3 or NO+O2 gas at 150 °C for 30 min then rinsed with N2 for 10 min. Finally, NO+O2 or NH3 was passed, and DRIFT spectra were recorded continuously until the adsorbed NH3 was depleted after 30 min [19]. 3 Results 3.1 NH3-SCR performance evaluation The NOx conversions of standard SCR between 120 ℃ and 600 ℃ over Cu-CHA catalysts with different hydrothermal aging time were calculated, as shown in Fig. 2. The T80 temperature window (the temperature range of NOx conversion over 80%) of the three samples were 317 ℃, 376 ℃, and 311 ℃, respectively. The HTA-24 h Cu-CHA catalyst showed the widest T80 temperature window from 205 ℃ to 581 ℃. However, the Fresh Cu-CHA and HTA-48 h Cu-CHA did not show an excellent activity temperature range than the HTA-24 h sample. Compared with the Fresh Cu-CHA, the temperature ranges of NOx conversion maintained at nearly 100% were significantly narrower for both HTA samples. The drop of NOx conversion between 250 ℃ and 450 ℃ was associated with the loss of Brønsted acid sites. Nevertheless, the increase in NOx conversion below 250 ℃ and above 450 ℃ contributed to the migration of ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu and the regeneration of CuO, respectively. The formation of N2O and NO2 as by-products during the NH3-SCR reaction were investigated to help understand the possible changes of standard SCR reaction mechanism before and after hydrothermal aging, which were displayed in Fig. 3. The N2O curves of the three Cu-CHA catalysts all exhibited significant N2O escape peaks caused by the decomposition of ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3) at around 240 °C, which were. As aging progressed, an increase in N2O production in the entire temperature range was founding the aging samples. Zhang et al. found that N2O production above 400 °C was associated with Cu species, which was mainly caused by Cu2+ on the six-membered ring [20]. Therefore, the increase of Cu2+ in the more stable six-membered ring structure could explain the rise in N2O production after hydrothermal aging. However, the drop of NO2 formation upon hydrothermal aging implied that the aging Cu-CHA catalyst was equipped with weaker NO oxidation capacity, which will be further discussed in the following section. 3.2 NH3-TPD The results of NH3-TPD over the Fresh and HTA-24 h Cu-CHA samples are shown in Fig. 4. In the initial 6–8 min, all the feeding NH3 was adsorbed on the Cu-CHA catalysts. Then, NH3 gradually reached the feeding concentration (1000 ppm) around over a few minutes. Further, the NH3 feeding was turned off at 20 min. In the following 20 min, weekly adsorbed NH3 was generally purged out with N2. NH3-TPD experiments were conducted at 10 ℃/min over the two samples after 40 min. Two distinct NH3 desorption peaks, centered at 250 ℃ and 400 ℃, were observed from 150 to 400 °C in the profiles of both fresh and aging catalysts. The low-temperature peak could be associated with desorbed NH3 on active Cu sites (ZCu(OH) and Z2Cu), while the high-temperature peak could be caused by desorption from Brønsted acid sites [21]. As shown in Fig. 4, the fresh sample possessed a higher NH3 storage capacity than the aging one. Therefore, the desorption curves of both samples were placed on the same graph for comparison, and the desorption curves were fitted with a Gaussian function to split the peaks. The results of the deconvolution of NH3 desorption are displayed in Fig. 5. According to the comparison results in the graph, and it can be concluded that the aging catalyst did not lose the adsorption on Lewis acid sites because hydrothermal aging induced the migration of Cu(OH)+ to the more stable Cu2+. However, a significant loss of adsorption capacity occurred at the Brønsted acid site, which was mainly due to dealumination during hydrothermal aging.The next section presents a more detailed investigation of NH3 adsorption capacity at different temperatures using in situ DRIFTs. 3.3 NH3 adsorption The DRIFTS spectra over the fresh Cu-CHA catalyst performed an obvious NH3 adsorption state, in which bands at 3737, 3712, 3670, 3613, and 3565 cm−1 appeared after NH3 saturation in the O-H bond stretching vibration region. The peaks at the Al-OH band over the aging Cu-CHA exhibited stronger intensity in the low adsorption temperature. Still, a quick drop happened on the Al-OH structure once over 200 ℃, indicated that Al-OH recovered to the initial state with the desorption of NH3. In the N-H bonds, three peaks (3332, 3271, 3179 cm−1) could be observed. The amount of NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, associated with 3332 cm−1, showed an obvious decrease in the whole temperature range. The desorption of NH3 from Lewis acid sites was found to be stronger at low temperatures, which in turn promoted the SCR reaction at these temperatures. However, only a small amount of NH3 was desorbed from Brønsted acid sites, and it still kept good adsorption although the temperature reached 300 ℃. So Brønsted acid sites had higher desorption energy barriers due than Lewis acid sites at low temperatures. A similar peak intensity variation trend appeared at 1628 cm−1 and 1486 cm−1. Notably, the peak located at 1570 cm−1 was the main factor for the reduction of Lewis acid sites ( Fig. 6). After hydrothermal aging, the peaks at 3613 cm−1 and 3565 cm−1 related to Al-OH-Si sites, as shown in Fig. 7, showed an obvious decrease because of a significant loss of adsorption capacity on Brønsted acid sites in CHA zeolites. According to our previous investigation, it was mainly caused by dealumination. Concerning the N-H bonds, the HTA sample showed higher peak intensity than the Fresh one at 3332 cm−1. On the contrary, the peak intensity at 3271 cm−1 decreased upon hydrothermal aging. The changes at 3332 cm−1 and 3271 cm−1 in the N-H bonds corresponded to the band located at 1617 cm−1 and 1490 cm−1. From the DRIFTS NH3 adsorption spectra of the above two samples, we could find that hydrothermal aging treatment enhanced the peak intensity at 1617 cm−1 while weakening the peak intensity at 1490 cm−1. It was concluded that the molecular NH3 connected to Cu2+ on Lewis acid sites increased upon hydrothermal aging. In the T-O-T bond region (1000 cm−1 to 850 cm−1), two well-resolved negative bands centered at 900 and 950 cm−1 are clearly visible which are corresponding to Z2Cu and Cu(OH) [22–25], when saturated with NH3. After aging, the relative content of Z2Cu species in isolated Cu2+ ions increased a lot while that of ZCu(OH) decreased obviously, which revealed that hydrothermal aging induced the migration of Cu2+ from CHA cages to D6R cages on Lewis acid sites. The above adsorption spectra of the Fresh and HTA sample illustrated that even if the NH3 adsorption of Lewis acid sites did not perform obvious changes upon hydrothermal aging, the migration of Cu species from ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu occurred on Cu species. It indicated that the most adsorption on Lewis acid sites was attributed to ZCu(OH) for the Fresh sample, while Z2Cu for the HTA sample. It was speculated that the migration of ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu might also have an impact on the NO adsorption capacity over the Cu-CHA catalyst, which will be further discussed. 3.4 NO oxidation performance evaluation NO oxidation tests based on a fixed-bed reactor were used to quantitatively evaluate the changes in the NO oxidation performance of Cu-CHA catalysts before and after hydrothermal aging. The variation of NO, NO2, and N2O concentration with temperature in NO oxidation reaction over the Fresh and HTA-24 h Cu-CHA catalysts are displayed in Fig. 8(a) and (b), respectively. The concentration of NO over the fresh Cu-CHA gradually decreased with the increase of temperature between 150 °C and 500 °C. Meanwhile, the corresponding concentration of NO2 increased with increasing temperature, which indicated that the reaction rate of NO oxidation reaction was faster as the rise of temperature. However, the NO conversion efficiency no longer increased or even dropped a bit when above 500 °C, which was attributed to the decomposition of NO2 to NO at high temperature and further inhibited the NO→NO2 reaction. The amount of N2O production was maintained less than 2 ppm, which indicated that it was difficult to oxidize NO+O2 to N2O directly, or the yield was low. Comparing the fresh and aged samples, it could be observed that the NO conversion efficiency of the aging catalyst was very low, almost no NO oxidation reaction occurred in the whole temperature range. It is well known that NO oxidation occurs on the surface of the active metal. Therefore, it is speculated in this study that the migration of ZCu(OH) and Z2Cu after aging induced the changes in NO adsorption and oxidation capacity on the Cu-CHA catalyst surface, which will be further discussed in the following. 3.5 NO+O2 adsorption and NH3-SCR reaction The oxidative adsorption capacity of NO was influenced by the migration of Cu2+ species during hydrothermal aging. The NO+O2 adsorption experiments at 150 ℃ were carried out by infrared spectroscopy to acquire information regarding the adsorbed NOx species, and the DRIFTs spectra with time over the fresh and aging samples were shown in Fig. 9. The Cu2+-NO peak at 1938 cm−1, assigned to NO coordinately adsorbed at the Cu ions, showed weaker intensity after aging, which implied that the NO adsorption on isolated Cu2+ was affected by hydrothermal aging. The two bands linked to NO2 - at 1660 and 1500 cm−1, which were widely accepted as the surface nitrate or nitro species adsorbed primarily on the transition metal active sites of catalyst, were very unstable, and their peak intensity detected at 150 ℃ were very weak [26,27]. The drop of IR intensity was also observed in the range of 1650 cm−1-1500 cm−1. The fresh Cu-CHA still showed an obvious peak at 1500 cm−1, but nearly no peak intensity over the HTA sample. The most distinct adsorption peaks at 1628 cm−1 and 1570 cm−1, assigned to bidentate nitrates linked to Cu sites and a nitro group produced by NO+O2 adsorption, appeared after the continuous passage of NO+O2 [26]. For fresh Cu-CHA, the peak intensity of 1570 cm−1 was much lower than that of 1628 cm−1, which implied that most NO+O2 adsorbed specie appeared on the surface of Cu-CHA catalysts was NO2 -. The wavenumber range of 1915–1968 cm−1 can be associated with Cu2+(NO)x, which was related to NO’s adsorption and oxidization. The similar vibration and mutual transformation between various (NO)x species could be illustrated in the bands from 1716 to 1831 cm−1 that was attributed to Cu+(NO)x [28]. A broad band between 2100 cm−1 and 2200 cm−1, assigned to NO+ species that weekly adsorbed on acid sites, was detected when the NOx flow was turned on [26,27]. The NO2 - ions is negatively charged fragments. Thus, it could be concluded that the appearance of NO2 - was accompanied by OH- substitution and the pairing of NO+ formation. (3.1) 4 N O + O 2 → 2 N O 2 − + 2 N O + (3.2) C u ( O H ) + + N O 2 − → C u ( N O 2 ) + + O H − (3.3) O H − + N O + → H O N O However, the two bands both decreased upon hydrothermal aging, which verified that the isolated Cu2+ species underwent its migration from ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu. Thus, we speculate that the loss of NO+O2 adsorption species was related to the migration from ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu. Figs. 10 and 11 showed the DRIFTS profiles of the changes with the continuous flux of NH3 after saturation of NO+O2 adsorption. Due to the low adsorption amount of NO+O2 on the fresh Cu-CHA catalyst, the peak intensity at 1628 cm−1 and 1570 cm−1 decreased rapidly with the increase of the NH3 adsorption peak in less than 20 min. At the 26th minute, the Cu-CHA sample was almost saturated with NH3 adsorption. But two distinct peak intensities located at 1628 cm−1 and 1570 cm−1 were still viewed in the DRIFTs spectrum. Therefore, it could be concluded that stable NH4NO3, which was difficult to converted, was formed in the reaction of NH3 and NO+O2 adsorbed species. In comparison, the peaks of the HTA sample profiles regarding the NOx adsorbed species did not change significantly with the addition of NH3. Only the NH3 indicator peak increased significantly, indicating that the standard SCR reaction on the HTA sample was unrelated to its NO+O2 adsorption. (3.4) C u ( N O 2 ) + + O H − + N H 3 → C u - [ N H 4 N O 3 ] The results could be concluded that activated NO adsorption mainly depended on active Cu species. ZCu(OH), as the dominant Cu2+ species over the fresh Cu/CHA catalyst, was the key Cu2+ species for NO+O2 adsorption, while the migrated Z2Cu did not contribute to NO-activated adsorption of the aging one. 3.6 NH3 adsorption and NH3-SCR reaction NH3 adsorption-saturated catalysts were exposed to a mixture of 500 ppm NO and 8% O2 for 30 min to study the reactivity and intermediate species of NH3 oxidization by NO+O2 at low temperatures. Figs. 12 and 13 respectively showed the DRIFTS profiles of the adsorbed NH3 oxidization of inflowing NO + O2 with time at 150 ℃ over the fresh and aging Cu-CHA catalysts. When the fresh Cu-CHA catalyst was saturated with NH3, obvious peaks of adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites (1617 cm−1) and Brønsted acid sites (1470 cm−1) were detected. After switching to NO+O2, the NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites was completely consumed at the 14th minute, and then the reaction between NH3 and NO + O2 was conducted on Brønsted acid sites. As the above adsorption spectra showed in Fig. 4, the peak at 1570 cm−1 decreased with the temperature rise, indicating that the NH3 adsorption related to this band easily desorbed and participated in the NH3-SCR reaction. However, the peak located at 1570 cm−1 did not perform a noticeable drop after the 14th minute, while a new peak appeared at 1628 cm−1 after the NH3 on Lewis acid sites was consumed, which revealed that the bridging and bidentate nitrate peaks centered at 1628 cm−1 and 1570 cm−1 emerged as the reaction proceeded [29]. With the introduction of NO+O2, the band at 1628 cm−1 corresponding to NO2 - species produced by NO+O2 adsorption increased slightly. The initial elevation of NH4 + was likely attributed to the formation of surface species (NH4NO2) in the first 14 min. It could be further oxidized to NH4NO3 with exposure to NO+O2, which was explained by bands’ appearances at 1570 cm−1 and 1596 cm−1 after 14th minute. These results indicated that the Lewis acid sits experienced the process of NH3 consumption to NOx adsorption or nitrate accumulation. The peak at 1514 cm−1, associated with the nitrites, disappeared soon with the increase of temperature, indicating the facile decomposition of nitrite. Meanwhile, the peak intensity at 1493 cm−1 and 1311 cm−1, corresponding to linear nitrites and monodentate nitrites, decreased as time went on due to its unstable structure. According to the analysis of NO+O2 adsorption, the nitrite might be formed by HONO and adsorbed NH3, then decomposing to N2 and H2O. NH4NO3 deposited on the Cu-CHA at 150 °C and would decompose to N2O and H2O once the temperature was raised to 225 °C according to reaction (3.9). (3.5) O H − + N O + → H O N O (3.6) N H 3 + H O N O → N H 4 N O 2 (3.7) N H 4 N O 2 → N 2 + 2 H 2 O (3.8) N H 4 N O 2 + 1 / 2 O 2 → N H 4 N O 3 (3.9) N H 4 N O 3 → N 2 O + 2 H 2 O For the aging Cu-CHA catalyst, a quick consumption of the NH3 adsorption revealed the reaction between adsorbed NH3 and gas-phase NO, which suggested the ‘E-R’ mechanism on Z2Cu. The nitrate peaks at 1628 cm−1 and 1570 cm−1 performed a distinct increase after hydrothermal aging, consistent with an increase in N2O production detected in the NH3-SCR activity evaluation. The experimental data confirmed that Z2Cu species with weaker NO adsorption and oxidation capacity promoted the formation of NH4NO3. 3.7 Reaction pathways of standard SCR for two Cu species at low temperature on Cu-CHA It was found that significant difference in the NO+O2 adsorption and oxidation capacity over the Fresh and HTA Cu-CHA catalysts was attributed to the migration of ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu during hydrothermal aging. The NH3-SCR reaction occurring on ZCu(OH) followed the ‘L-H’ mechanism, while the entire NH3-SCR on Z2Cu followed the ‘E-R’ mechanism. The above in situ DRIFTs study revealed that NH3 on Lewis acid sites and NH4 + on Brønsted acid sites acted as active intermediates in the NH3-SCR reaction over Cu-CHA catalysts. The main adsorbed species of NOx on the ZCu(OH) were NO+, NO2 -, and NO3 -, in which NO3 - originated from NO2 - further oxidation [9]. We speculate that if Cu(NO2) is not consumed or further oxidized, it will absorb on the zeolite surface and form Z-O-NO+. According to the results of co-adsorption, it is difficult for nitrate to form competitive adsorption of NH3. In addition, the rapid reaction between NO2 - and NH3 will inhibit the further oxidation of NO2 - to form NO3 -. And NO+ species were not detected to be involved in the reaction. Therefore, NO2 - is considered to be the major active NOx species. Since the NH3 absorbed by the Lewis acid site shows more reactivity than the NH4 + ion, the NH3-SCR reaction may mainly follow the reaction pathway between the NH3 adsorbed by the Lewis acid and the NO2 - directly formed. The oxidation of NO to NO2 through dimerization and disproportionation reactions played an important role in the NH3-SCR reaction that followed the ‘L-H’ mechanism. The further oxidation of NH4NO2 on ZCu(OH) led to the formation of bidentate nitrates over the fresh Cu-CHA catalyst. However, pre-adsorbed NH3 substances on the aging catalyst could effectively be reacted with gas-phase NO to form H2NNO and then produce N2 in the subsequent reactions. Due to the poor NO adsorption capacity on Z2Cu, the bridging nitrates formed in the NH3-SCR reaction were not easily reduced to N2, resulting in more NH4NO3 accumulation on the surface of the aging catalyst, thus producing more N2O. We refer to the DFT study of the NH3-SCR reaction pathways on Cu species by Chen et al. [8] to complement the redox process of Cu2+ in standard SCR reaction process, in which the pathways for Cu+ to be oxidized and NH4NO3 decomposition to H2NNO are both cited in this work. Based on the above analysis, the possible reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR reaction on ZCu(OH) and Z2Cu was proposed as the following. The mechanisms of the standard SCR reaction on ZCu(OH) and Z2Cu are respectively displayed in Figs. 14 and 15. (3.10) N H 4 N O 3 + 3 N O → 2 H N O 2 + H 2 N N O → N 2 + H 2 O 4 Conclusion To summarize, hydrothermal aging was conducted on the Cu-CHA catalysts prepared by IE method, and their activity and N2O selectively in NH3-SCR were investigated systematically. The activity tests’ results showed that the Cu-CHA catalyst retained high NOx conversion at low temperatures after hydrothermal aging, while an increase of N2O formation appeared as by-products in the reaction of NH3 and NO+O2. The experiments of NH3 adsorption revealed that the migration of ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu prevented the drop of adsorption on Lewis acid sites. However, it caused a loss of NO’s adsorption and oxidation, as characterized by NO oxidation and DRIFTs of NO+O2 adsorption experiments, which affected the NH3-SCR mechanism. The wave spectrum of in situ DRIFTs confirmed the notable difference in the NH3-SCR mechanism between Cu species of ZCu(OH) and Z2Cu at the same reaction conditions. The NH3-SCR reaction occurring on ZCu(OH) followed the ‘L-H’ mechanism, where NH3 combined with products that oxidize NO to NO2 via dimerization and disproportionation reactions to produce the key intermediates as NH4NO2 and HONO. However, the entire NH3-SCR on Z2Cu followed the ‘E-R’ mechanism, in which adsorbed NH3 could effectively be reacted with gas-phase NO to form H2NNO and then produced N2 in the subsequent reactions. Furthermore, the bridging nitrates on Z2Cu, which formed in the NH3-SCR reaction, were not easily reduced to N2, resulting in more NH4NO3 accumulation on the surface of the aging catalyst, thus producing more N2O. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the experiments combined with activity tests and characterizations were conducted to investigate the influence of hydrothermal aging (HTA) on the reactivity of NH3-SCR over a Cu-CHA catalyst. The results showed that the NOx conversion efficiency can reach more than 80% below 225 ℃ in the reaction between NH3 and NO+O2 after hydrothermal aging, but it increases the N2O production. The wave spectrum of in-situ DRIFTs confirmed the notable differences in the NH3-SCR mechanism between Cu species of ZCu(OH) and Z2Cu at the same reaction conditions. The NH3-SCR reaction occurring on ZCu(OH) followed the ‘Langmuir-Hinshelwood’ (L-H) mechanism, where NH3 combined with products that oxidize NO to NO2 via dimerization and disproportionation reactions to produce the key intermediates as NH4NO2 and HONO. However, the entire NH3-SCR on Z2Cu followed the ‘Eley-Rideal’ (E-R) mechanism, in which adsorbed NH3 effectively reacted with gas-phase NO to form H2NNO and then produced N2.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of migration of ZCu(OH) to Z2Cu upon hydrothermal aging on the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over a Cu-CHA catalyst
